channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Audio long read: A new kind of solar cell is coming — is it the future of green energy?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03882-x

Perovskite–silicon ‘tandem’ photovoltaic panels could lead to cheaper electricity production.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: A new kind of solar cell is coming — is it the future of green energy?
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: The Nature Podcast highlights of 2023
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04046-7

The team select some of their favourite stories from the past 12 months.
item.dc:title: The Nature Podcast highlights of 2023
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe
Noah Baker
Dan Fox
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Super-propulsion: how sharpshooting insects flick their pee
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04167-z

High-speed cameras reveal tiny insects employing a physical phenomenon, never-before seen in a natural system to avoid drowning in their own urine
item.dc:title: Super-propulsion: how sharpshooting insects flick their pee
item.dc:creator: Noah Baker

item.title: From the archive: waltzing mice, and Louis Pasteur’s beer battle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04078-z

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: waltzing mice, and Louis Pasteur’s beer battle

item.title: Festive parody songs from the Nature Podcast
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04170-4

The Nature Podcast team have rewritten two popular holiday songs in honour of some of the biggest science stories of in 2023.
item.dc:title: Festive parody songs from the Nature Podcast
item.dc:creator: Noah Baker

item.title: How AI works is often a mystery — that's a problem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04154-4

The inner workings of many AIs are mysterious, but with increasing use of such technologies in high stakes scenarios, how should their inscrutable nature be dealt with?
item.dc:title: How AI works is often a mystery — that's a problem
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Reindeer can activate sleep mode while eating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04034-x

Putting the brain into sleep mode helps to maximize food intake during bountiful Arctic summers.
item.dc:title: Reindeer can activate sleep mode while eating

item.title: How an AI-powered lion became a teaching tool
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04152-6

The mascot for King’s College London helped Andrés Gvirtz to teach a class, with a little help from generative artificial intelligence.
item.dc:title: How an AI-powered lion became a teaching tool
item.dc:creator: Andrés Gvirtz

item.title: How a surge in organized crime threatens the Amazon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04087-y

The global community needs to break the web of transnational crime networks and corruption threatening one of the world’s largest carbon sinks.
item.dc:title: How a surge in organized crime threatens the Amazon
item.dc:creator: Bram Ebus

item.title: Will superintelligent AI sneak up on us? New study offers reassurance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04094-z

Improvements in the performance of large language models such as ChatGPT are more predictable than they appear.
item.dc:title: Will superintelligent AI sneak up on us? New study offers reassurance
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: Neutrino secrets could be revealed by Earth’s atmosphere
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04085-0

Scientists typically look at the skies or take to the laboratory to probe the neutrino’s properties. But neutrinos produced in Earth’s atmosphere could reveal this long-sought information — and the experiments are already well under way.
item.dc:title: Neutrino secrets could be revealed by Earth’s atmosphere
item.dc:creator: Josh Spitz

item.title: Citations show gender bias — and the reasons are surprising
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03474-9

Gender bias in paper citations is less common among younger scientists, but it still plays a part in making women’s research less visible.
item.dc:title: Citations show gender bias — and the reasons are surprising
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: Saleemul Huq (1952–2023), climate visionary
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04166-0

A relentless climate scientist who was the voice of the voiceless in the global climate fight.
item.dc:title: Saleemul Huq (1952–2023), climate visionary
item.dc:creator: Achala C. Abeysinghe

item.title: A tale of Silk Road violence as told by a lake’s mud
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04017-y

Soot and other remnants of fires record ancient warfare along the storied trade route.
item.dc:title: A tale of Silk Road violence as told by a lake’s mud

item.title: What were some of the biggest stories of 2023? Join us for the Nature Podcast quiz!
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04161-5

In a game of twenty questions our contestants stretch their memories to remember some of the science stories that made headlines this year.
item.dc:title: What were some of the biggest stories of 2023? Join us for the Nature Podcast quiz!
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Polar bear fur-inspired sweater is thinner than a down jacket — and just as warm
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04145-5

The synthetic fibre is an aerogel coated with polyurethane and is flexible, washable and wearable.
item.dc:title: Polar bear fur-inspired sweater is thinner than a down jacket — and just as warm
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Contact-tracing app predicts risk of SARS-CoV-2 transmission
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04063-6

The risk of catching COVID-19 as calculated by a smartphone app scales with the probability of subsequently testing positive for the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, showing that digital contact tracing is a useful tool for fighting future pandemics.
item.dc:title: Contact-tracing app predicts risk of SARS-CoV-2 transmission
item.dc:creator: Justus Benzler

item.title: Politics and the environment collide in Brazil: Lula’s first year back in office
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04042-x

Brazil’s left-wing President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva grapples with deforestation, fossil-fuel pledges and commitments to Indigenous communities — all while having to work with a conservative Congress.
item.dc:title: Politics and the environment collide in Brazil: Lula’s first year back in office
item.dc:creator: Meghie Rodrigues

item.title: AI consciousness: scientists say we urgently need answers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04047-6

Researchers call for more funding to study the boundary between conscious and unconscious systems.
item.dc:title: AI consciousness: scientists say we urgently need answers
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Welcome to your post-apocalyptic bunker rental!
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03891-w

A home away from home.
item.dc:title: Welcome to your post-apocalyptic bunker rental!
item.dc:creator: Wendy Nikel

item.title: How research managers are using AI to get ahead
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04160-6

For those at the interface of funding organizations and the scientific community, platforms such as ChatGPT can tackle menial tasks and free up time for relationship-building work such as coaching and mentoring.
item.dc:title: How research managers are using AI to get ahead
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: How I became the ‘hoodie girl’: attending conferences as a neurodiverse scientist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04157-1

Biostatistician Penny Robinson explains why conferences and networking events present challenges for neurodiverse scientists and suggests some simple fixes.
item.dc:title: How I became the ‘hoodie girl’: attending conferences as a neurodiverse scientist
item.dc:creator: Anna Napolitano

item.title: Why 2023 was a bittersweet year for Brazilian science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04041-y

Expectations were high after Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva won the presidency. But some scientists are frustrated at the slow pace of change.
item.dc:title: Why 2023 was a bittersweet year for Brazilian science
item.dc:creator: Meghie Rodrigues

item.title: Global population profile of tropical cyclone exposure from 2002 to 2019
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06963-z

Global population profile of tropical cyclone exposure from 2002 to 2019
item.dc:title: Global population profile of tropical cyclone exposure from 2002 to 2019

Digital measurement of SARS-CoV-2 transmission risk from 7 million contacts

item.title: Stable blue phosphorescent organic LEDs that use polariton-enhanced Purcell effects
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06976-8

Stable blue phosphorescent organic LEDs that use polariton-enhanced Purcell effects
item.dc:title: Stable blue phosphorescent organic LEDs that use polariton-enhanced Purcell effects
item.dc:creator: Haonan Zhao
Claire E. Arneson

item.title: Protracted neuronal recruitment in the temporal lobe of young children
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06981-x

Protracted neuronal recruitment in the temporal lobe of young children
item.dc:title: Protracted neuronal recruitment in the temporal lobe of young children

item.title: This GPT-powered robot chemist designs reactions and makes drugs — on its own
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04073-4

A system called Coscientist scours the Internet for instructions, then designs and executes experiments to synthesize molecules.
item.dc:title: This GPT-powered robot chemist designs reactions and makes drugs — on its own
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: What ChatGPT is and what it's not: a three minute guide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04156-2

A whistle-stop tour under the hood of Chat GPT in which we ask whether we should be calling LLMs intelligent in the first place
item.dc:title: What ChatGPT is and what it's not: a three minute guide
item.dc:creator: Richard Van Noorden
Shamini Bundell

item.title: The Nature Podcast festive spectacular 2023
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04151-7

Games, seasonal science songs, and Nature’s 10.
item.dc:title: The Nature Podcast festive spectacular 2023
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Noah Baker

item.title: Disproportionate declines of formerly abundant species underlie insect loss
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06861-4

An analysis of more than 500 sites distributed worldwide finds that declines in the abundance of terrestrial insects are attributable mainly to decreases in species that were formerly abundant, rather than being the result of losses of rare species.
item.dc:title: Disproportionate declines of formerly abundant species underlie insect loss
item.dc:creator: Roel van Klink
Diana E. Bowler
Konstantin B. Gongalsky
Minghua Shen
Scott R. Swengel
Jonathan M. Chase

item.title: Mitochondrial dysfunction abrogates dietary lipid processing in enterocytes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06857-0

Mitochondria have a pivotal role in the transport of dietary lipids in enterocytes, a finding that might have relevance to understanding the aberrant gastrointestinal function in patients with mitochondrial disorders.
item.dc:title: Mitochondrial dysfunction abrogates dietary lipid processing in enterocytes
item.dc:creator: Chrysanthi Moschandrea
Vangelis Kondylis
Ioannis Evangelakos
Marija Herholz
Farina Schneider

item.title: RNA-mediated symmetry breaking enables singular olfactory receptor choice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06845-4

Messenger RNAs transcribed from olfactory-receptor genes may have non-coding functions that include recruitment of transcriptional enhancers and inhibition of potentially thousands of competing alleles to ensure stable transcription of a single allele.
item.dc:title: RNA-mediated symmetry breaking enables singular olfactory receptor choice
item.dc:creator: Ariel D. Pourmorady
Elizaveta V. Bashkirova
Andrea M. Chiariello

item.title: Minute-scale oscillatory sequences in medial entorhinal cortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06864-1

Neural population activity in the medial entorhinal cortex of mice can be organized into ultraslow oscillatory sequences, with periods extending up to the minute range.
item.dc:title: Minute-scale oscillatory sequences in medial entorhinal cortex
item.dc:creator: Soledad Gonzalo Cogno
Horst A. Obenhaus
Ane Lautrup
R. Irene Jacobsen
Claudia Clopath

Flavio Donato

Edvard I. Moser

item.title: Moiré synaptic transistor with room-temperature neuromorphic functionality
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06791-1

We report the experimental realization and room-temperature operation of a low-power (20 pW) moiré synaptic transistor based on an asymmetric bilayer graphene/hexagonal boron nitride moiré heterostructure.
item.dc:title: Moiré synaptic transistor with room-temperature neuromorphic functionality
item.dc:creator: Xiaodong Yan
Zhiren Zheng

Mark C. Hersam

item.title: Online searches to evaluate misinformation can increase its perceived veracity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06883-y

Searching online to evaluate the truthfulness of false news articles increases the probability of believing the false news articles.
item.dc:title: Online searches to evaluate misinformation can increase its perceived veracity
item.dc:creator: Kevin Aslett
Zeve Sanderson
William Godel
Nathaniel Persily
Jonathan Nagler
Joshua A. Tucker

item.title: Structures of the promoter-bound respiratory syncytial virus polymerase
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06867-y

A study reports cryogenic electron microscopy structures of the respiratory syncytial virus polymerase bound to its genomic and antigenomic viral RNA promoters.
item.dc:title: Structures of the promoter-bound respiratory syncytial virus polymerase
item.dc:creator: Dongdong Cao
Yunrong Gao
Zhenhang Chen
Inesh Gooneratne

Bo Liang

item.title: Cytoneme-mediated transport of active Wnt5b–Ror2 complexes in zebrafish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06850-7

In zebrafish embryos, active complexes of Wnt5b and its membrane-bound receptor Ror2 are transported between cells via cellular protrusions called cytonemes to initiate paracrine Wnt5b signalling in cells that do not endogenously express the receptor.
item.dc:title: Cytoneme-mediated transport of active Wnt5b–Ror2 complexes in zebrafish
item.dc:creator: Chengting Zhang
Lucy Brunt
Yosuke Ono
Sally Rogers
Steffen Scholpp

item.title: Emergence of replication timing during early mammalian development
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06872-1

Genome-wide replication timing maps of mouse embryos from the zygote to the blastocyst stage were generated using single-cell Repli-seq, shedding light on the establishment of the epigenome at the beginning of mammalian development.
item.dc:title: Emergence of replication timing during early mammalian development
item.dc:creator: Tsunetoshi Nakatani
Tamas Schauer
Luis Altamirano-Pacheco
Kyle N. Klein
Andreas Ettinger
Mrinmoy Pal
David M. Gilbert
Maria-Elena Torres-Padilla

item.title: Autonomous chemical research with large language models
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06792-0

Coscientist is an artificial intelligence system driven by GPT-4 that autonomously designs, plans and performs experiments by incorporating large language models empowered by tools such as internet and documentation search, code execution and experimental automation.
item.dc:title: Autonomous chemical research with large language models
item.dc:creator: Daniil A. Boiko
Robert MacKnight
Ben Kline
Gabe Gomes

item.title: The PfRCR complex bridges malaria parasite and erythrocyte during invasion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06856-1

Structural studies show how the PfRCR complex of Plasmodium falciparum forms a bridge between erythrocyte and parasite membranes, and how PfCyRPA-binding antibodies neutralize invasion through a steric mechanism, opening the way to new approaches in rational vaccine design.
item.dc:title: The PfRCR complex bridges malaria parasite and erythrocyte during invasion
item.dc:creator: Brendan Farrell
Nawsad Alam
Melissa N. Hart
Abhishek Jamwal
Robert J. Ragotte
Hannah Walters-Morgan
Simon J. Draper
Ellen Knuepfer
Matthew K. Higgins

item.title: Three-dimensional atomic structure and local chemical order of medium- and high-entropy nanoalloys
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06785-z

Atomic electron tomography is used to determine the 3D atomic positions and chemical species of medium- and high-entropy alloy nanoparticles and quantitatively characterize the local lattice distortion, strain tensor, twin boundaries, dislocation cores and chemical short-range order.
item.dc:title: Three-dimensional atomic structure and local chemical order of medium- and high-entropy nanoalloys
item.dc:creator: Saman Moniri
Yao Yang
Jun Ding
Yakun Yuan

Long Yang

item.title: Cryo-EM structures of PP2A:B55–FAM122A and PP2A:B55–ARPP19
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06870-3

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the PP2A:B55 holoenzyme bound to its inhibitors ARPP19 and FAM122A show distinct binding modes of the two inhibitors.
item.dc:title: Cryo-EM structures of PP2A:B55–FAM122A and PP2A:B55–ARPP19
item.dc:creator: Sathish K. R. Padi
Margaret R. Vos
Rachel J. Godek
James R. Fuller
Thomas Kruse
Jamin B. Hein
Jakob Nilsson
Matthew S. Kelker
Rebecca Page
Wolfgang Peti

item.title: Discovery of a structural class of antibiotics with explainable deep learning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06887-8

An explainable deep learning model using a chemical substructure-based approach for the exploration of chemical compound libraries identified structural classes of compounds with antibiotic activity and low toxicity.
item.dc:title: Discovery of a structural class of antibiotics with explainable deep learning
item.dc:creator: Felix Wong
Erica J. Zheng
Jacqueline A. Valeri

James J. Collins

item.title: 2D materials ratchet up biorealism in computing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03791-z

A transistor made from atomically thin materials mimics the way in which connections between neurons are strengthened by activity. Two perspectives reveal why physicists and neuroscientists share equal enthusiasm for this feat of engineering.
item.dc:title: 2D materials ratchet up biorealism in computing
item.dc:creator: Frank H. L. Koppens
James B. Aimone
Frances S. Chance

item.title: Vaccines reduce the risk of long COVID in children
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04032-z

A study shows that US children who received mRNA COVID-19 vaccines have some protection against developing long-lasting symptoms of the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2.
item.dc:title: Vaccines reduce the risk of long COVID in children
item.dc:creator: Shannon Hall

item.title: Cancer-fighting CAR-T cells could be made inside body with viral injection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03969-5

Scientists are devising ways to edit the genomes of immune cells without having to extract them from those being treated.
item.dc:title: Cancer-fighting CAR-T cells could be made inside body with viral injection
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Nostalgia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03889-4

A night to remember.
item.dc:title: Nostalgia
item.dc:creator: Sean MacKendrick

item.title: Online search results can increase belief in misinformation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03665-4

To counter misinformation, people are often advised to check the truth of claims by searching online. Five experiments show that this can actually increase people’s belief that false or misleading articles are true, an effect that might be driven by low-quality search results.
item.dc:title: Online search results can increase belief in misinformation

item.title: Surge in extreme forest fires fuels global emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04033-y

Climate change and human activities have led to more frequent and intense forest blazes over the past two decades.
item.dc:title: Surge in extreme forest fires fuels global emissions
item.dc:creator: Xiaoying You

item.title: Scientists question cancer tests that use microscopic nematode worms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03733-9

Some doctors say a troublingly high number of cancer-free people have tested positive on the tests sold by a Japanese start-up.
item.dc:title: Scientists question cancer tests that use microscopic nematode worms
item.dc:creator: David McNeill
Momoko Suda

item.title: Large language models direct automated chemistry laboratory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03790-0

Automation of chemistry research has focused on developing robots to execute jobs. Artificial-intelligence technology has now been used not only to control robots, but also to plan their tasks on the basis of simple human prompts.
item.dc:title: Large language models direct automated chemistry laboratory
item.dc:creator: Ana Laura Dias
Tiago Rodrigues

item.title: ‘Explainable’ AI identifies a new class of antibiotics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03668-1

An artificial-intelligence graph neural network was trained on experimental data and used to identify chemical substructures that underlie selective antibiotic activity in more than 12 million compounds. This led to the discovery of a class of antibiotics with in vitro and in vivo activity against Gram-positive bacteria, including Staphylococcus aureus.
item.dc:title: ‘Explainable’ AI identifies a new class of antibiotics

item.title: Daily briefing: Criticism hits nematode cancer tests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04168-y

Doctors have raised concerns that a commercial cancer test produces high levels of false negatives and false positives. Plus, a surge in extreme forest fires fuels global emissions and what quantum theory implies about determinism.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Criticism hits nematode cancer tests
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Atomic electron tomography reveals chemical order in medium- and high-entropy alloys
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03656-5

Medium- and high-entropy alloys are hugely promising materials in metallurgy and catalysis, but their atomic-scale structure — and how that relates to their properties — is not well understood. A powerful method is beginning to reveal their secrets, with hopes for engineering better materials in the future.
item.dc:title: Atomic electron tomography reveals chemical order in medium- and high-entropy alloys

item.title: To build a better world, stop chasing economic growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04029-8

The year 2024 must be a turning point for shifting policies away from gross domestic product and towards sustainable well-being. Here’s why and how.
item.dc:title: To build a better world, stop chasing economic growth
item.dc:creator: Robert Costanza

item.title: Mysterious ultraslow and ordered activity observed in the cortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03795-9

Neurons with a role in navigation fire sequentially in mice, forming patterns that repeat every minute or so — but which are neither spatially organized, nor related to any visible behaviour.
item.dc:title: Mysterious ultraslow and ordered activity observed in the cortex
item.dc:creator: Gilles Laurent

item.title: End the glaring inequity in international science collaborations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04022-1

The world’s natural-science research ecosystem remains focused on the priorities of high-income countries. Funders, publishers and scholarly databases can do more to help to rebalance that.
item.dc:title: End the glaring inequity in international science collaborations

item.title: Zebrafish embryo cells need no receptors to receive signals from afar
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03659-2

Thin cellular protrusions called cytonemes can transport ligand–receptor complexes from a signal-producing cell to a receiving cell in the developing zebrafish embryo. Even cells lacking the receptor can be activated by this signalling system.
item.dc:title: Zebrafish embryo cells need no receptors to receive signals from afar

item.title: Daily briefing: Sexism is a waste of money
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04159-z

Sexism harms people and is one of the biggest sources of public funding inefficiency. Plus, 12% of bird species probably driven to extinction by humans and COVID-19 vaccines lower children’s risk of long COVID.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Sexism is a waste of money
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: High-resolution structures of two phosphatase–inhibitor complexes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03833-6

Progression into the final phase of the cell cycle is driven mainly by protein phosphorylation, although it also requires the inhibition of phosphatase proteins, such as the PP2A:B55 complex. The structures reveal how PP2A:B55 binds to two of its inhibitors.
item.dc:title: High-resolution structures of two phosphatase–inhibitor complexes

item.title: From the archive: scientific spelling, and ancient Egyptian art
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03789-7

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: scientific spelling, and ancient Egyptian art

item.title: Humans might have driven 1,500 bird species to extinction — twice previous estimates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04065-4

Humans are probably responsible for the extinction of 12% of bird species, many of which were never documented.
item.dc:title: Humans might have driven 1,500 bird species to extinction — twice previous estimates
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Viruses wrap up bacterial defence systems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03796-8

Bacteria use diverse defences against viral predators called bacteriophages. A method to identify antibacterial counter-defences in viral genomes has revealed striking modes of defence inhibition.
item.dc:title: Viruses wrap up bacterial defence systems
item.dc:creator: Tim R. Blower
Stineke van Houte

item.title: Black holes, love and poetry — an artistic exploration of intimacy and adventure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04023-0

A book by physicist Kip Thorne and artist Lia Halloran explores the mysteries of space through poetry and paintings.
item.dc:title: Black holes, love and poetry — an artistic exploration of intimacy and adventure
item.dc:creator: Ron Cowen

item.title: Daily briefing: How to stand out from the crowd when applying for a scientific job
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04150-8

Tips from career experts on how to land a scientific position even in a struggling economy. Plus, the science events to watch for in 2024 and cats play fetch, but only on their own terms.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How to stand out from the crowd when applying for a scientific job
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Has your research influenced policy? Use this free tool to check
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04070-7

Sage Policy Profiles scans a database of 10 million documents to show researchers where their papers have been cited.
item.dc:title: Has your research influenced policy? Use this free tool to check
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla
